Literature Review: Engineered wood has emerged as a promising sustainable material with diverse applications across various industries. This literature review explores recent advancements in engineered wood technologies, focusing on their potential for sustainable development and innovative applications.Transparent wood has garnered significant attention in recent years due to its unique optical properties and potential applications in energy-efficient buildings. Li et al. (2016) demonstrated a method for creating transparent wood by removing lignin and replacing it with a polymer, resulting in a material with high optical transmittance and excellent mechanical properties. This breakthrough has opened up new possibilities for using wood in windows and solar cells, potentially reducing energy consumption in buildings.The thermal management capabilities of engineered wood have also been extensively studied. Zhu et al. (2017) developed a wood-based material with anisotropic thermal conductivity, which can efficiently direct heat flow in specific directions. This property makes it suitable for applications in thermal energy storage and passive cooling systems. Furthermore, Song et al. (2018) created a super-insulating wood material by partially removing cell wall components and introducing air gaps, achieving thermal conductivity lower than that of conventional insulation materials.Environmental remediation is another area where engineered wood has shown promise. Chen et al. (2019) developed a wood-based material capable of efficiently removing heavy metal ions from water. By introducing functional groups onto the wood surface, they achieved high adsorption capacities for various pollutants, demonstrating the potential of engineered wood in water purification applications.The nanofluidic properties of wood have been explored for applications in ion transport and energy generation. Xia et al. (2020) demonstrated that aligned nanochannels in wood can be used for efficient ion transport, opening up possibilities for wood-based ionic devices and energy storage systems. This research highlights the potential of wood as a sustainable alternative to synthetic materials in nanofluidic applications.In the field of energy storage, wood-derived materials have shown promise for use in batteries. Li et al. (2021) developed a wood-based electrode material for sodium-ion batteries, utilizing the natural hierarchical structure of wood to enhance ion transport and storage capacity. This approach offers a sustainable alternative to conventional battery materials, potentially reducing the environmental impact of energy storage technologies.The mechanical properties of engineered wood have been significantly improved through various modification techniques. Frey et al. (2018) demonstrated a method for creating densified wood with a strength-to-weight ratio exceeding that of many metals and alloys. This high-performance wood material has potential applications in lightweight structural components for automobiles and aerospace industries, offering a sustainable alternative to energy-intensive materials like steel and aluminum.Nanocellulose, derived from wood, has emerged as a versatile material with applications in various fields. Klemm et al. (2018) reviewed the production methods and applications of nanocellulose, highlighting its potential in areas such as composites, packaging, and biomedical applications. The high strength, low density, and biodegradability of nanocellulose make it an attractive material for sustainable product development.The use of engineered wood in construction has also seen significant advancements. Ramage et al. (2017) discussed the potential of engineered wood products, such as cross-laminated timber, in high-rise construction. These materials offer advantages in terms of sustainability, construction speed, and carbon sequestration compared to traditional building materials.Despite the promising advancements in engineered wood technologies, challenges remain in scaling up production and ensuring long-term durability. Zhu et al. (2019) reviewed the current state of wood nanotechnology and identified key areas for future research, including improving the stability of modified wood materials and developing more efficient production processes.In conclusion, engineered wood has demonstrated remarkable potential as a sustainable material for various applications, ranging from energy-efficient buildings to advanced energy storage systems. The ability to tune the properties of wood through chemical and physical modifications has opened up new possibilities for utilizing this renewable resource in high-performance applications. As research in this field continues to advance, engineered wood is poised to play a crucial role in developing sustainable technologies and addressing global challenges related to energy, environment, and resource utilization.
